description:
Tilletiaria anomala UBC 951 is a species of fungus that belongs to the phylum Basidiomycota. It is a smut fungus, meaning it is a member of the order Ustilaginales, which are plant pathogens that infect and replace the host plant's reproductive structures with their own fungal spores.

Tilletiaria anomala UBC 951 was first isolated from a plant host in British Columbia, Canada, and is currently maintained in the University of British Columbia (UBC) fungal culture collection as strain UBC 951. The fungus exhibits an unusual life cycle and morphology compared to other smut fungi, which has led to its classification in the separate genus Tilletiaria.

Detailed scientific studies of the biology and genetics of this specific strain, UBC 951, are limited in the available literature. However, the genus Tilletiaria as a whole is known to produce distinctive teliospores (fungal spores) that differ in structure from the more common smut fungus spores. Further research on the ecology, host range, and molecular genetics of this particular isolate could provide valuable insights into the diversity and evolution of smut fungi.
